div.head: Report:
div.p: The aim of this experiment was to exploit anomalous X-ray scattering to draw out high Bragg intensity contrast in a difference experiment where small structural changes arise from photoexcitation. We focus on photoinduced structural changes of a metastable light-activated complex, [Ru(NH 3 ) 4 (H 2 O)(SO 2 )](tosylate) 2 , where the SO 2 ligand photoisomerises from η 1 (end-bound) to η 2 (side-bound) bonding to the Ru metal. (See Scheme 1).

We performed full structure collections on both the ground state and photoexcited structures, each both using standard 0.7 Å radiation and at the Ru K edge to capture the anomalous X-ray scattering. We also measured the XANES spectra of each structure in situ.

Preliminary data analysis indicates that the experiment was a great success. The photoinduced η 2 state is clearly identifiable (Fig. 1). Moreover, the high-resolution data obtained are of sufficient quality for chargedensity analysis (Fig. 2).

Analysis of the AXS data and XANES spectra is ongoing. The latter display the anisotropy expected from single-crystal analysis; to assist in interpreting these, we are employing DFT modelling using the CASTEP code. Preliminary results show good agreement for this system, as well as for reference data on metal phthalocyanates (which are standard model compounds for XANES modelling) obtained from Phil Pattison. Figure 1 Photo-difference map showing a model of the ground state (in wireframe) applied to data from the photo-excited state. The deep holes around the ground-state S and O atoms indicate that these have moved in a significant fraction of the unit cells, and the small peaks nearby show two new positions for S1 and one for O2.
